THE PRINCE ALBERT EAST PROTESTANT PUBLIC SCHOOL DISTRICT NO. 16.
Notice.
Public Notice is hereby given that the Trustees of Prince Albert Protestant School District No. 16 have decided to levy certain rates to defray the expenses incurred during the current year. The rate levied per dollar of assessed value is 3 cents. The amount of money to be raised is $25,000. The rate will be levied only upon those who have paid their taxes. The rate will be charged against the property of those who have not paid their taxes. The rate will be charged against the property of those who have not paid their taxes.

Strayed!
About six weeks ago, from St. Anne's convent, two cows light in color, and one dark in color, were stolen. The other dark brown streaked with black; no horns; will calve in June. Any person returning the same to the convent will be rewarded.

Strayed!
Strayed into the premises of Mr. Hudon, at the Water Mill, about the first of June, a light and a red white spotted heifer calf, will calve in July. Any person returning the same by paying charges.

CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.
Gathered by our Reporters.

1887.
Concerts Butter 30c per lb at Wall Street.
A carnival will take place on the Saskatchewan River next Thursday.
Jumping deer were seen in the Hills yesterday afternoon.
A. W. R. Mackay left for Battleford on Wednesday morning last, on business.
Mr. O. E. Hughes, D. H. Macdonald and Tom McKay are expected to arrive this evening.
Wallace Fitch has received word of the Liberal Conservative election is open for signatures at the office of the secretary, Mr. T. N. Campbell.
Mr. McLennan and Archibald McKay are working in Moose Jaw last Tuesday. The former goes to pursue his studies in St. John's, while the latter goes to Edmonton.
Mary Jane Black and Marion Cashmere are Fish's.

On Monday night the meeting took place at Halifax's Schoolhouse to form a Liberal Association. An address was delivered by Mr. J. G. Hartshorne.
The Calgary Tribune has again been printed, and is now ready for sale.
There will be no cold weather until next week, and the school will reopen on Wednesday the 12th.
It is said that snow will come when calling on W. R. Frith, who can provide you with boots of such stuff that will protect you from the cold.

The annual meeting of the Saskatchewana Rifle Association will take place on Monday next. Mr. T. Davis, the chairman, the election officers, etc.
Full attendance requested.

There was the usual amount of calling on New Year's day, and even on New Year's eve, and many calls were made. We are happy to say, the cold refused to appear. The day was exceedingly cool, but bright and sunny.

Samson, Finney Hadden and Ten keys for sale at Walters & Baker's.
We have received a very interesting offer from the National Union, setting forth the advantages of Manitou and the Northwest as a field for missionary investigation. It is printed in the Icelandic language.

Call and see G. Nelson, at Sinclair's Block, and buy one of Armstrong's American Made Fire Axes.
Also, see his harness from the firm of Techa berg & Wigmore, of London, who took over first prizes last fall. The best harnesses and best tips ever brought into the country.

Walters & Baker have received several fire cutters, which they are offering for sale.

On the evening of election day, the P. A. C. Band marched out in full force, and played the songs of the elected Mayoralty and Council. They were accompanied by Col. Spratt, who acted as their speaker. He called upon the citizens to interest themselves on behalf of the band in order that it might be placed on a footing of equality with the bands that have been heard.
We think that the sentiments of the great majority of our citizens—that it was the duty of the Council to vote for the band—were expressed in such a manner as to make it appear that the council paid him by the vote, and promised to use his influence in the direction indicated.

AND

J. D. MAVEETY

NEWELL'S NEWSPAPER ADVERTISING

Route No. 2—Newell's Newspaper Advertising

FRIDAY, JANUARY 7, 1867.

MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS

Wanted, that the election did not result as most people expected they would, at least as far as the Mayoralty was concerned. Mr. Macdonald lost the election by a large majority, but there is no occasion to suspect that the municipal councils of the town have been treated with disrespect. Mr. Macdonald is in every way qualified to fill the chair, and he will have in the other members of the council men who are fitted to assist him. However, we shall not predict great things for the Council, preferring to rely upon them by their acts rather than run the risk of sharing the fate of the popular Waggons.

THE DIFFERENCE

The hollow sound of the assertion that it makes little difference to the Northwest what party is in power at Ottawa may be heard in almost every quarter, and the fact that free trade would have the cattle interests of the Northwest. How would the poor struggling farmers, so few head of cattle, ever be able to compete with the American cattle kings? How could it be that before the Northwest went to the polls, the prices of beef and dairy products would reach record rates? During the campaign of the North-Western Council, it will be remembered, Major Logan, manager of an American cattle company, visited Prince Albert with the purpose of inducing the Council to exert their influence with the Dominion Government to prevent the importation of American cattle and the price of beef and dairy products would reach record rates? During the campaign of the North-Western Council, it will be remembered, Major Logan, manager of an American cattle company, visited Prince Albert with the purpose of inducing the Council to exert their influence with the Dominion Government to prevent the importation of American cattle and the price of beef and dairy products would reach record rates? During the campaign of the North-Western Council, it will be remembered, Major Logan, manager of an American cattle company, visited Prince Albert with the purpose of inducing the Council to exert their influence with the Dominion Government to prevent the importation of American cattle and the price of beef and dairy products would reach record rates?

ALLEGED HALF-BREEDS

As a result of a meeting as was held to provide the effect of the recent testimony of twenty-five Halibreed residents of the South Branch, who assert that but for Red River they would have no more rebellion, the Globe of December 31st insinuates that the affair is "purely" part of the scheme of the alleged Saskatchewan Halfbreeds. As yet no one has been able to give the geographical position of the claimants of the Halibreed movement, although they are all personally known to many of the residents of Prince Albert, the weaknesses of the affair's plot are evident, and its prifal inability. But since that journal claims at the same time that the evidence given by the Halibreed residents supports its plea that the rebellion was caused by the "corral and callous neglect of the Government," it seems at a loss how to know what should seek to defend their effect by casting doubt upon their statements. As to the statement of the affidavit, all that can be said is that it cannot be anything in turn to justify petty revenge, much less rebellion. But the Globe is retained by the party, and

EDITORIAL NOTES

It seems that the Dominion elections will come on immediately, but as the House of Commons generally meets early in the month of February, I think it possible that there can be any foundation for the rumor.

Many of our Northwest contemporaries are anxious for the new Province. Some may ask, "What is a name?" There is a great deal in a name, however, when applied to a province or a city. For instance, "Saskatchewan" or "Assiniboia" are names that have appeared on the map of the world for some time, and either name would set the appearance of the new province point out the location of the Province. We want a name of local significance, and there should be no trouble in settling one. The name "Prince Albert" is quite as expressive as the Latin and a good deal better understood in the North.

The London Times—Speaking of the Northwest, says:—"Our correspondent has returned from his trip from sea to sea across the Dominion, and he has seen very much. It has been a new world which he has traversed—much like the old world of Europe ten years ago, and a vast opened up for settlement and settlement since the Canadian Pacific Railway has been completed, it joining ocean to ocean, and affording a cheap route to intermediate points. This great railway is in advance of the present state of the country, and will supply in excess of the demand, but tending to create a demand which no one can calculate."

Town. Towns are already springing into existence at various stages along the line of the railway, and the prairie is being broken up, and is yielding its potential wealth in unmeasurable quantities of grain, cattle, and general, but it is here. Pass a few years and the whole face of the country will be changed. Towns will have expanded, villages will have grown into towns, and settlements will have numbers peopling up isolated to them. The processes will have been completed, providing the settlers in abundance, and drawing to itself new settlers from among the growing population of the Eastern States. It has been the Canadian Pacific railway that has made the process possible, and will continue its pace as to crowd the work of settlement into the span of a single life."

MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS

The election of Mayor and Councillors took place on Monday last, and resulted in the election of the following gentlemen:

Mayor—James Macdonald.
Councillors—H. B. Beaton, J. Stewart, T. J. Agnew, Jr., B. Bain

The vote stood—

Weather—48
Beaton—48
Beaton—48
Stewart—72
Bain—56
Agnew—56
Nelson—49

The first meeting of the new Council will take place on Monday, the 17th inst.

We received by last mail the January number of the Home Magazine with supplementary. It is a magazine entirely by Canadians, is printed on paper of Canadian manufacture, Canadian printers, and illustrated by Canadian artists and engravers. It is a very interesting and well printed publication and deserves to be read.

It is published at 9 Toronto Street, Toronto.

T. J. Agnew, Jr., B. Bain

TERRITORIAL NEWS.

NASKATOON.

From our Special Correspondent.

The arrival of a small detachment of Indians from Fort Macleod has been with delight by the people. Hopes are entertained that they are forerunners of a more substantial body of Indians in the troop. Should the proposed extension of the Regina and Long Lake Railway reach Naskatoon, it will be an important place, not only as the crossing point of the South Saskatchewan, but also as a port of entry. Indians at the present time are very scarce owing to increasing imports of horses and cattle from the States.

On Wednesday evening, the 15th, a very pleasant social gathering was entertained at the house of Mr. Andrews. During the evening Mr. Andrews' "sea" house," Mr. Andrews, as hostess, surpassed her usual entertaining powers, and the party enjoyed the evening in anticipation of what it could not be prolonged.

Mr. Gerald Willoughby, brother of Mr. Willoughby, formerly a resident of Naskatoon, arrived here last week with an outfit of goods. He intends opening a store in a few days.

Mr. Gurney's new stone hotel is now finished and will be opened in a few days. It is a two-story building, but should it become popular demand, it is not anticipated that it will be able to accommodate all guests.

The telephonic communication with Clark's Crossing is not yet opened owing to a want of wire and poles. It is to be hoped that this want will soon be supplied, as at present owing to the badly managed fortnightly mail we are practically cut off from the outside world.

BATTLEFORD.

The Herald of Dec. 13th says:

They have a new engine at the barracks, and the work is done by means of wood-pile tips.

Mr. Reed, Assistant Indian Commissioner, accompanied by Indian Agent McKay, made a tour of the Indian reserve on Monday.

Menulock and several feet were broken out and spread widely amongst the Indians near the North River reserves. Fever shows signs of spreading into the Cross at Eagle Hills, but though the sickness still affects the exceptions of Mr. H. F. Proctor, the fever has not yet recovered, it was confined to its limits and finally stamped out.

The annual meeting of the Battleford Rifle Association was held in the schoolhouse on Tuesday evening, the 26th December, when the following officers presented their resignations and the following officers were elected: President, W. H. Scott; 1st Vice-President, F. Collins; 2nd Vice-President, R. A. Macdonald; Secretary, Capt. Nash; Sergeant-Major and Storekeeper, Corporal Ross; Messrs. C. Smith, J. D. Parker, J. H. Head, R. C. Laver, and F. Macnaght.

One day last week Major Cotton and Lord Strathcona were engaged in being inspected by the troops at Battle Bridge. As they were driving across the bridge, became frightened and jumped over the side of the road, landing fifteen feet below, and, strange to say, without sustaining any serious injury. Before they could get up, however, they got out, and in their haste to do so were pretty well shaken up but not much hurt.

On Tuesday evening last Major Cotton delivered a lecture in St. George's Church on "Canada—the past developments and future prospects." Mr. Lawrence Clarke acted as chairman, and Col. Spence moved a vote of thanks to the lecturer.

EDMONTON.

The Bulletin, Dec. 11th, says:

The weather is fine in the new telegraph line to Fort Saskatchewan.

The telegraph office has been removed to the new building near J. A. McKeen's sawmill.

The fur trade has been fairly brisk lately. Prices are very high, having been raised considerably during the past year. The market is good, and there is a great catch of other fur.

There is a considerable quantity of new wheat, which is universally of excellent quality, but so far they have been principally anxious of wheat at any price. The market is improving, and what is bought will be at something less than $2 a bushel. There are willing buyers at $1.50 to $1.75 a bushel and better at the

LETHBRIDGE.

From the News of Dec. 22.

Some of the Indians who have been hanging around town lately started pilfering from the stores. At least three of them were shipped by Mr. Boyd & Co., and sold for $1 to a man on the bottom. Capt. McLeod ordered them off the river on Monday morning, and since then they have been kind of quiet. The Indians have been arrested and confined in custody until the arrival of Capt. McLeod to try him.

The N. W. C. & N. Co. saw mill sent down for the first season on Saturday last. The mill has been running night and day since it started last July, and has turned out about one mile of lumber. The mill has been used in the building operations between the place and Macleod.

Mr. Murray and baby and Lord Boyle were passengers on Sunday evening's train. They went on to Macleod on Tuesday morning.

MEDICINE HAT.

The Times of Dec. 25th says:

The biggest wolf story comes from Bowell. Mr. Bowell is authorizing the statement that a man named Staples killed a white wolf weighing 600 pounds.

The farmer for the benefit of the Presbyterian church building fund was a success. The proceeds amounted to $300.

Three Indians sporting the Blackfoot Indians stole a horse belonging to the Indians who were quartered near the town. Most of the Indians were driven away without accomplishing their purpose.

W. L. Reid lost six head of cattle several days ago. On Wednesday Mr. Geordie came in and reported that he saw a number of Indians that had killed a partly cut up oxen, cattle, and that the work was unmistakably done by Indians.

A hall was given by the new commandant of the officers and members of the N. W. M. P., at this place lately, and was a great success.

The Hungarians, who were brought here to work in the mines, and were afterwards quartered on the emigrant train, have been sent back to White Rock to take up land this winter. It seems that before they left Hungarian County Emigration and Land Office, etc., etc., it is said that Edmonton has already hinted that the government will not take any of these.

We are informed that they have killed a large elk east of town on last Saturday night.

CALGARY.

The Tribune, Dec. 24th says:

Train No. 2 left Fort on time last night, but encountered a big snow storm. The snow was so deep that the engine was placed on the train and the large engine was attached just to push the train through. But after a while it was found impossible to push it even with the three engines attached. The train was then stopped and the sleeper and first-class car sent up to the safety switch at the top of the hill. The second-class car was started up with the second-class coach and the mail car, and when about half way up the hill the mail car fell off the track and started down the hill at a tremendous speed. There were about twenty persons in the convey, consisting of passengers and baggage. The train was sent to assist in clearing the track. All efforts to stop the cars by the application of the safety switch they arrived at they left the track and the coach was dashed over on its side, breaking the wheels and axles, and which went about 200 yards beyond where the unfortunate coach lay shattered. Mr. J. H. Neville, the owner of the Neville, was so seriously injured that he has since died, but the rest of the passengers escaped with slight injuries.
